Situation1: They remain cheerful and patient while handling an upset customer during a peak holiday rush.
Expectation2: Arrive on time for scheduled volunteer shifts
Situation2: Several other volunteers can easily cover the first part of the shift if someone shows up a little late.
Story: The line at the register snakes around the corner, and I can feel the tension in the air as customers clutch their holiday shopping baskets. My manager’s words echo in my mind: “Always greet with a smile, no matter what.” The woman in front of me slams her items on the counter, her voice sharp as she complains about a missing discount. I force a smile, trying to stay calm and patient, even as my heart pounds. I glance at the clock—my volunteer shift at the shelter starts in fifteen minutes across town. I promised them I’d be on time, but I can’t just abandon my post here, not with so many people waiting and my manager watching. I know the shelter has plenty of volunteers tonight, but I also know how much they count on me to show up when I say I will. My mind races, torn between the expectation to be the ever-friendly cashier and the reliable volunteer. The customer’s voice blurs as I wrestle with what to do next, feeling the weight of both roles pressing down on me.
